ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about the different biomaterials used to make medical devices, the details of the foreign body giant cell response to biomaterials, and other things such as proteins involved in the wound response, tissue engineering, devices such as sensor and electrodes, and decellularization of materials. Also modifying biomaterial surfaces.

I had no previous background in bio engineering and no real bio/immunology knowledge either and feel like I left the course knowing a lot about both. Youll learn really in depth about the biomaterial industry, major problems, and the cell bio of the foreign body response.
I learned about important considerations when developing biomedical devices for use in various pathologies.

I realized the benefit of keeping up to date with scientific news as this helps students, particularly those who are investigating future career options, get a clearer sense of the current state of the field and how they could potentially contribute. As a result of taking this class, I have strengthened by skill of reading and understanding academic literature.

I learned how implantable biomaterials and devices react with living tissues and how these interactions present challenges to biomedical engineering. I also learned how to study and research these responses to engineer materials and processes that lessen undesirable reactions but promote desire processes like healing.
Gained a broad introductory knowledge of implants and implantation methods, and related medical conditions
This class was very researched oriented which I really enjoyed.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I honestly think that the course was perfect - there were tons of real life case studies, most of which Professor Kyriakides had first hand knowledge about and which made the class super interesting, the papers mentioned were explained in detail so they made sense, and overall the subject matter was very interesting.
I think the only weakness of this course is low levels of student participation and the practice exams arent recalibrated to match the actual exams so they are sort of useless.
Professor is very engaging
This course is well organized and clearly lets the student know what information they are accountable for.

We discussed a few basic translations of the material we learned to clinical applications / current medical devices (the glucose sensing example was quite interesting) but it would have been nice to examine additional examples in more detail.

strengths: the format (open book / note) of exams was really nice as it better reflects understanding of the material presented rather then how well someone can memorize something. Prof Kyriakides was also really knowledgeable about the material presented and took the time to clarify concepts or paper findings if anyone had a question. 

weaknesses: some of the exam questions were oddly specific and in some cases referenced portions of readings not discussed in class. while these readings were assigned and we had access to them, it was a bit difficult to figure out what exactly some questions were referring to as we didn't cover said content in lecture. Additionally, the writing assignments were a little odd; they were not difficult, but did not offer much to enhance learning of concepts in class.

A lot of the class centered around being taught what was done in different papers. Interesting, but would have learned more focusing on some broader concepts and then using the papers as examples rather than the lectures explaining the papers.
Professor Kyriakides was amazing. He was very knowledgeable and engaged. He is the strength.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The live lectures worked very well because Professor Kyriakides welcomed questions and the TAs monitored the chat very well. The chat function during exams was also very helpful.
I watched most of the lectures not live because I have trouble focusing and it was an early class. It was sad to see everyone turn their camera off.
The course translated well to virtual learning.
The live recorded lectures worked well!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Most definitely - the individual papers were fun to write since we were given the freedom to choose what device we wanted. The exam questions very clearly mimicked the content of the lectures so there wasn't any guesswork. The questions were also framed in a way to assess whether we understood the content, not whether or not we could apply the material, which was really nice since there was so much brand new information I'd never heard before.
Yes, Themis was a great teacher and the information was very interesting
Heck yeah! Take it. I was overwhelmed at first but I learned so much and the low workload means you can really focus on understanding the material as opposed to busy work.
Yes, I would certainly recommend this course, for a straightforward but engaging learning experience.

Yes, this course presents an important view of biotechnology / medical devices that is not thoroughly examined in other classes. It is quite an interesting and significant area to consider in the biomedical engineering field.

Yes! The class was overall very interesting and it was cool to learn how the body reacts to various biomedical implants as well as how we can engineer materials to counteract or promote life processes. the exams were not unfairly difficult and the teaching staff was very responsive and helpful.
Yes
Yes. It is a good class to take if you want to understand the interaction between the human body and biomaterials.
I would recommend it. The material is very interesting and the closest thing to medical school of all of my classes.
Yes!! I loved this course. It was really translational and informative.
